title.narrative: Providing lifesaving support to minimize the risk of COVID-19 spreading in communities and schools in Nangarhar, Faryab, Balkh, Takhar and Kunduz

description.narrative:
Following its declaration as a global pandemic and its first official reported cases in country February/March 2020, Afghanistan is likely to be significantly affected by COVID-19 due to its weak health system and limited capacity to deal with major disease outbreaks, in what is already one of the most complex humanitarian crises across the globe. COVID-19 is a potentially deadly virus, especially for those who are immunocompromised and/or elderly. Due to an already strained healthcare system, infection prevention and control (IPC) measures are urgently needed in Afghanistan to prevent the spread and ultimately save lives. ACTED will provide WASH services to communities and schools in ten districts across five provinces (Maymana district in Faryab, Mazar-e-Sharif in Balkh, Kunduz and Imam Sahib in Kunduz province, Taloqan and Rostaq in Takar and Achin, Deh Bala, Dur Baba and Goshta in Nangarhar) to reduce the transmission of the virus and ultimately relieve the healthcare system from additional cases and strain, saving lives. ACTED will target 49,994 men, women, boys and girls with IPC sensitization campaigns over the media of leaflets, posters, radio broadcasts, mobile soundsystem broadcasts and mosque speaker broadcasts.
WHO promote handwashing as one of the single most effective ways to reduce the transmission of the virus. Alongside the IPC sensitization campaigns, ACTED will also install 800 portable and 180 semi-portable wash stations in areas where there are already high WASH needs and regularly top them up with soap. 3,000 of the most vulnerable households will also receive WASH Cluster-endorsed COVID kits. In addition, ACTED will also coordinate with local authorities to cover key gaps by disinfecting key and common public places.
To ensure children’s right to an education is upheld whilst also not putting them and vulnerable communities at risk of transmitting and spreading the virus, ACTED will advocate to and work with PEDs and DEDs to ensure school re-opening plans are created. Once made, ACTED will help to implement the safe re-opening in at least six schools over the five provinces. To attract children back to schools, and especially girls who are at greatest risk to not return, ACTED will construct or rehabilitate handwashing facilities plus latrines to build back better. This will be in at least six schools and reach at least 3,090 men, women, boys and girls.
